To run the code, you should download the datas from Kaggle : https://www.kaggle.com/c/state-farm-distracted-driver-detection/data.

As the kaggle style, you should put the codes into the directory named code, put the datas into the directory named input.

I am also getting `Illegal instruction (core dumped)` when running the mxnet examples.  So it is not a Keras issue.

I am getting the error with Python 3.5.2 as well.  

I will try to compile from source.  I have these new Intel v4 Xeons and they've been a headache at times.
@peterfig which mxnet example did you run?

`cnn_text_classification` and others.

I just installed the mxnet-mkl package and `cnn_text_classification` is working.  I bet the Keras stuff will work now too.  So, I think it is fair to say the Python mxnet package will not work out of the box for all Intel processors.

@peterfig this might be the case. AVX support was turned on by default before 0.11.1 so it could cause problems. Starting from 0.11.1, it supports run-time detection so similar problem shouldn't happen any more. If you'd like to test it, you can get 0.11.1 nightly build using `pip install --pre mxnet` (with other appropriate flags). Let me know how it goes if you decide to give it a try.
Absolutely, I'll give it a whirl.  If you let me know what the "other appropriate flags are" because I have no idea.
Sorry for the confusion. For example, you may want to turn on `--user` for installing in user directory. Or if you already have a pip-installed mxnet, you may want to turn on `--upgrade`.

I tried `pip install mxnet==0.11.1b20171007` and it works!  However, `mxnet-mkl`was using all my cores whereas this one appears to be using only two.  This one is much more efficient, getting 153 samples/sec with 2 cores while `mxnet-mkl` was getting 450 samples/sec with 32 cores.

Anyhow, it works, thanks much!
Good to know. BTW the `mxnet-mkl` also has the nightly version and can be installed with the same method.

`mxnet-mkl-0.11.1b20171007` is also only using two cores, and is a little (10%) faster than the `.
mxnet==0.11.1b20171007`

What's the number of physical cores on your machine?
Try `export OMP_NUM_THREADS=$NUM_PHYSICAL_CORES`.

https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/how_to/perf.html#intel-cpu
I've got two CPUS for a total of 20 physical cores; setting that environment variable doesn't seem to change anything.  But the 0.11.0 mxnet-mkl used them all automatically.

just change occurrences of ```Dataframe``` to ```Dataset[_]``` in MXNet.scala to match the new signature of ```Predictor``` in Spark 2.x
You will have to change the version of spark in the pom before building.

This issue says closed, right?

Is the MKL build built with GPU support (even though only CPU is being used)?  GPU and CPU builds have different OpenMP characteristics, regardless of whether GPU is being used. This difference will be relaxed somewhat in the 1.0 release.
`mxnet-mkl` is not built with GPU support.

@sxjscience assert len(shared_group.execs) >= len(self._context) is ok. But some other things must be known by user.
If the the batch size is `N` and devices are '0,1,2,3' for the `shared_group`, the batch size for each `exec` is `N/4`. So the batch size for the new `exec` to be created using existing shared one should also be `N/4` for shape consistent of shared arguments. Thus, the batch size for the new `exec_group` should be `N/4 * 2` if devices are `0,1` or any others containing two. This may be a burden for users who are not familiar with mxnet low level code. Otherwise, I saw the `shared_group` is just used by bucketing in which devices will not changed. Right? If I'm wrong, I will fix it. Thanks.

Hi @szha,

I want to add CI build into upstream Jenkins.
MXNet.jl is quite passive. We do not get any notification about api breaking changes or new feature added.
Currently, we are using Travis nightly build to discover api changes. :p 

e.g.
- https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/pull/267
- https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/pull/288

My understanding is that you can achieve this by adding job to the [Jenkinsfile](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/Jenkinsfile).
Adding @mbaijal in case I missed something.
I am not aware of anything being added into master since 0.11 that would affect that. It would have to be investigated.

@formath We should be able to share the parameters even if the batch_size is different. In fact, in my usage case, I have one Module that's built on 2 GPUs for training. I want to create another shared module that only uses 1 GPU for testing. In this case, `len(shared_group.execs)=2` and `len(self._context)=1`
@sxjscience Nice https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/8185

A lot of tedious work.
We have to agree on what we do with cases like:
int x = 4; float y = foo(x);
This code  will always cast back to an int at the end, so y may be pretty much garbage. Which is in contrast to the usual expectations when you do something  like 
float y = exp(x) 
where you will actually get the same result as if you would do 
float y = float(exp(double(x)));

Well, it is always DType in = DType out, right?

I am happy with the current solution. It reflects the state we had before, but is now doing the right thing for DType = double.

@eric-haibin-lin row_ids corresponding to embedding or continuous features are removed and I think distributed version should be okay. But my machine seems have some weird problems with protobuf. Could you please check the distributed version?


@sergeykolychev, the benchmark shows a slight performance boost when using `zip()` without callbacks, and it would also be closer to the python code.  Should this patch also retool the uses of `zip()` to take advantage of this?

Could you add a test for these math ops and check them against numpy with all data types? We should try to match numpy with as high precision as possible.

Sorry for asking more work from you. But since we are looking into this now might as well get it right.

The second commit refactors most of the uses of `zip()` to avoid the callback form, though the handler still supports that call style.  Both tests and examples seem happy to me.

If the user doesn't use multiple inheritance, i.e. just `class Net(gluon.Block)` an exception will be raised if unknown parameters are passed. That is because Block inherits from `object`, passes these unknown parameters to the `object.__init__`, which will then raise an Exception. So the behaviour is essentially equivalent to the current implementation.

Consider however `class Net(gluon.Block, someOtherClass)`. Then the `super().__init__` call actually calls `someOtherClass.__init__`, so the behaviour depends on `someOtherClass`. But that is exactly what this PR is trying to achieve 

```

In [19]: class A(object):
    ...:     def __init__(self, **kwargs):
    ...:         super().__init__(**kwargs)
    ...:

In [20]: A()
Out[20]: <__main__.A at 0x7f8d6c2e4940>

In [21]: A(test=1)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-21-cb80bf2d7b82> in <module>()
----> 1 A(test=1)

<ipython-input-19-7242f9e16fa1> in __init__(self, **kwargs)
      1 class A(object):
      2     def __init__(self, **kwargs):
----> 3         super().__init__(**kwargs)
      4

TypeError: object.__init__() takes no parameters

```

Hi @loweew 

Can you provide more details about your fine-tuned model? For instance, what command you used in order to fine-tune? I'm assuming when you say you used fine-tune.py you used [this](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/fine-tune.py).

Also, will it be possible to share your fine-tuned model?

Also, while we are at this, are you fine-tuning this model: http://data.mxnet.io/models/imagenet-11k-place365-ch/ (resnet-50) so that I can try reproducing this at my end?

Hello,

I can add tests for operators which are callable by users. I'd do:
- forward: comparison Numpy, for float32, float64. It is not clear to me whether NumPy does
   computations in float32, or does not internally use float64 in any case
- finite difference tests in float64. It is our experience that such tests do not work with float32

I don't think I can test things for other DType, because NumPy only does things for float32 and float64.

@piiswrong : Do you have other DType in mind? I am not familiar with these exotic "half" types. What is important for them, is that cast from/to float is implemented.


I can add the following tests:
- Forward

python fine-tune.py --pretrained-model imagenet11k-place365ch-resnet-50 --data-train train.rec  --data-val val.rec --batch-size 360 --num-classes 227 --num-examples 115000 --data-nthreads 24 --lr 0.001 --lr-factor 0.1 --lr-step-epochs 30,60,90 --mom 0.9 --wd 0.0001 --disp-batches 500 --top-k 5 --max-random-h 30 --max-random-s 30 --max-random-aspect-ratio 0.30 --max-random-rotate-angle 90 --max-random-shear-ratio 0.15 --max-random-scale 2 --num-epochs 150  --gpus '0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7' --model-prefix ./imagenet11k-places-resnet-50

Unfortunately, I cannot provide the model. I would imagine fine-tuning on any data set for a few epochs where number of classes != 1000 should be sufficient to repro the issue, but I haven't yet done that.
